With it he raised the Skeletal Hoards to bring all of the tribes under his control.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Ga&#39;rlath&#39;s Skeletal Assault is a fantasy set featuring the villainous boss on his animated three-headed, flying. skeletal mount. With two animated skeleton arms men chained to the front and two animated skeleton arches captured in the belly of his beast only the bravest, strongest, and most intelligent warriors will dare to challenge him as he leads his hoard on a rampage of destruction and vengeance.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Whether the creator is looking for a set to act as the grand final battle, a recurring threat to the It is made for all the drone fans, professional as well as hobbyist, to play and explain how drone movie films are made.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The movie drone is inspired from the model Aerochrome 14 made by the german drone manufacturer <a href=\"http://coopercopter.com/\">CooperCopter</a>.<br />\r\nIt is a an octocopter offering enough payload capacity to bring a professional movie camera on board (such as a ARRI Alexa or a RED EPIC).<br />\r\nIts design and size provide the necessary stability for high quality pictures.<br />\r\nIt is equipped with a 3 axis gimbal (heading, pitch and roll), that allows to orient the camera independently from the drone structure, and virtually in any direction.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The crew consists of the <strong>drone pilot</strong>, the <strong>photographer</strong> and the <strong>director of photography</strong>.<br />\r\nHaving two operators (photographer and pilot) for the drone is often preferred in the movie industry to share the workload.<br />\r\nThe pilot is in charge of bringing the drone to the right location and fly along the desired flight path. He is in charge as well of ground and air safety.<br />\r\nThe photographer focuses on composing the right shot: he chooses the right focal length, focus, exposition and camera orientation.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The pilot uses a radio remote control to pilot the drone. He either watches the drone in VLOS (Visual Line Of Sight) or uses a HUD (Heads Up Display) to see what the drones sees with its auxiliary camera. Either on his remote or the HUD, he cans also monitor relevant flight parameters (flight time, battery capacity, eventual warning and error messages, etc...)<br />\r\nThe photographer uses a remote control to set the camera heading, pitch and roll, and all other necessary camera parameters (focal length, sensitivity, diaphragm aperture, shutter speed, area of focus, etc...). He uses a HUD to have a live preview of the shot.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The director of photography insures that the footage is consistent with his vision and with the rest of the movie.<br />\r\nAs he is a director, he is equipped with his chair, his clap and of course his megaphone!</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Enjoy!</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Images created with KOCHLABZ models, LDD, MECABRICKS, BLENDER, LDD2POVRAY, POVRAY and GIMP</p>\r\n", "user_comments_locked": false, "tags": ["drone", "drones", "movie", "movies", "film", "filmset", "pilot", "photographer", "director", "clapboard", "osd", "hud", "vlos", "remote This time&nbsp;with higher quality images so you can see the project like never before! This is my own design test chamber featuring some of the most important details of the Portal 2 testing chambers! This project is&nbsp;also my first project built in LDD (Lego digital designer)&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>The set</strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p>This set contains many details from Portal 2 test chambers, one of the harder things to replicate was the damaged, but still operational look that many of the chambers had. This project features: a simplified exit door, an aperture science&nbsp;500 megawatt super button for the cube, a blank cube, a thermal discouragement beam (a&nbsp;laser), a removable glass panel, a turret, a&nbsp;discouragement redirection cube and of&nbsp;course&nbsp;Chell with her portal gun. There are other parts as well that you can use to customize the chamber, these are pictured at the front project and are: 2 configurable panels, an extra cube and button, a hand operated button&nbsp;and&nbsp;a discouragement beam&nbsp;receiver.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The concept of the chamber is to have a set that is full of accurate detail, but easily changed to a different look by adding the extra components and removing others. The chamber is raised off the floor so a pit containing the cube can exist in the floor above, and maybe to replicate the escape scenes in the game. This test&nbsp;as it is without the extra pieces, can be solved!&nbsp;Move the redirection cube so the beam is re-directed on to the turret, destroying it, then&nbsp;portal down into the pit behind the turret to obtain the cube. (shown in the third picture) Then place the cube onto the large button to open the door and escape!</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>Details</strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p>I am unsure of how many pieces the set contains, but I assume it is in the 100-250 range, maybe more. The doors don&#39;t actually open, and the laser can&#39;t easily be extended any further, and the set doesn&#39;t have any portals, but that may come later in an update. The large button, turret, glass panel and all plants can be removed for construction of your own tests using the extra pieces, however the damaged wall, door, laser&nbsp;and pit are all permanent and cannot be easily removed. If this becomes a official LEGO set, then&nbsp;printing or a decal would be needed on the blank cubes to give them the in game textures, also Chell and maybe her portal gun would need printing to add further detail.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>If you like this project and want to see it as a set, then please support! Not sure why... Anyways, I got this idea after building my mini LEGO city. I had lots of space on the roof of the office building, so I built a &nbsp;helicopter with <strong>three seats</strong>,&nbsp;<strong>a table</strong>, and a&nbsp;<strong>pilot&#39;s seat&nbsp;</strong>complete with&nbsp;<strong>realistic controls</strong>. I hope to have this become a set because I had to build this myself. I have always wanted a good&nbsp;looking, passenger helicopter for my mini-figs, but I have been too lazy to make one. This set will allow kids to get a cheap set with only one thing in it: a simple helicopter, which is all they wanted and&nbsp;needed.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Of course, there already IS a LEGO VIP helicopter. You may be familiar with it, LEGO set 3222 &quot;Helicopter Limousine&quot;. But personally, I think it is not only a little, but VERY expensive. $200 dollars! That is what makes this set so great. The building is not only the offices for Capitol&#39;s West Coast operations it also houses recording studios and an echo chamber which make up Capitol Studios.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>My model includes the tower and the retangular building at its base. Printed pieces provide the Hollywood Walk of Fame and the Hollywood Jazz mural.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The Hollywood Walk of Fame lists eight stars at 1750 North Vine Street for:</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>John Lennon</strong><strong>, Paul McCartney</strong><strong>, George Harrison</strong><strong>, Ringo Star</strong><strong>, Roy Orbison</strong><strong>, Garth Brooks</strong><strong>, Neil Diamond</strong><strong> and Buddy Holly.</strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>The Hollywood Jazz mural </strong>was designed and painted by artist Richard Wyatt in1990. Recently Capitol Records and Richard Wyatt joined forces to remake the mural in mosaic form.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The mural&#39;s official name is <em><strong>&ldquo;Hollywood Jazz: 1945-1972&rdquo;</strong></em> and features jazz legends <strong>Chet Baker, Gerry Mulligan, Charlie Parker, Tito Puente, Miles Davis, Ella Fitzgerald, Shelly Manne, Dizzy Gillespie, Billy Holiday, Duke Ellington, and Nat &lsquo;King&rsquo; Cole</strong>.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Ideally I would like the set to include printed pieces featuring the original design; however, for my submission I have recreated the mural using mini-figures (the best I could do using Digital LEGO so any resemblance to a real person would be a miracle - I am sure that the LEGO art department could do them justice) .</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Thanks for looking at my project and please tell your friends.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>If you like Architecture sets you may like some of my other projects.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n", "user_comments_locked": false, "tags": ["Capitol Records", "Capitol Studios", "Capitol", "Records", "Architecture", "Hollywood", "Beatles", "Jazz"], "state_entered_at": "2016-07-20T06:18:17.000Z", "user": {"alias": "Eiffleman", "id": 859077, "uuid": "f6cc0079-5c7d-4086-9816-09da85d0de58"}, "product_image_url": null, "stats_followers_count_short": "15", "price_usd": null, "product_id": null, "stats_supporters_count_short": "49", "support_ending_at": "2017-07-20T06:18:17.000Z", "product_description": null, "published_at_formatted": "Jul 20, 2016", "image_url": "https://dp1eoqdp1qht7.cloudfront.net/community/projects/f16/7b6/148094/2567489-o_1ao3dhtr71uhv17lb1kek49obc9j-full.jpg", "state_id": 149, "stats_comments_count": 22, "stats_views_count_short": "312"}, {"stats_days_left": 356.5114226947801, "updated_at": "2016-07-28T06:05:12.000Z", "image_tile_url": "https://dp1eoqdp1qht7.cloudfront.net/community/projects/a47/0d1/148133/2566481-o_1ao245df81jfi1eq91pi31prggioo-thumbnail-UvpGzgmrZQeOhw.jpeg", "stats_supporters_count": 19, "published_at": "2016-07-20T06:14:24.000Z", "sold_out": null, "stats_followers_count": 11, "stats_comments_count_short": "6", "id": 148133, "user_id": 1110384, "uuid": "6c670708-754a-474f-9dce-6bbcf18ba563", "product_image_tile_url": null, "title": "ROB the Robot", "state": {"name_short": "Gathering Support", "alias": "gathering_support"}, "stats_views_count": 166, "body": "<p>ROB the robot is a small, durable, posable Lego action figure. Headquarters), including characters such as Jimmy Olsen, Red Tornado, Indigo/Brainiac 8, Non and Maxwell Lord, however assumed many fans would like to receive &lsquo;classic&rsquo; variations of such figures before these CW &lsquo;variants&rsquo;.&nbsp; I also heavily considered including the show&rsquo;s unique incarnation of Martian Manhunter (/Hank Henshaw), however thought my set may then appear too similar to LEGO&rsquo;s 76040 Brainiac Attack, and given the choice of my inspiration of the S01E18 <em>&lsquo;Worlds Finest&rsquo; </em>scene, would not be show-accurate (though I&rsquo;d still love to see him produced in an accompanying polybag set, such as the official LEGO 30603 Batman Classic TV Series &ndash; Mr. Freeze).&nbsp; Original characters such as Winn Schott Jr, Astra In-Ze and Alex Danvers were omitted due assumed preference of original comic characters and likely a general lack of interest from potential consumers.</li>\r\n\t<li>Originally, I planned for the set to also include a NCFD Fire Engine, however quickly abandoned that idea, to reduce the set&rsquo;s piece count and keep the set at a largely affordable price, instead including a newly designed fire hydrant as a placeholder.</li>\r\n\t<li>The set is specifically designed so that it can easily be integrated into other LEGO sets and themes for maximum creativity and playability, especially LEGO City and other Super Heroes sets.</li>\r\n\t<li>Please note I have not included the necessary minifigure prints and piece decals on builds, especially the helicopter, in order for viewers to use their imagination and so as not to detract from my build.</li>\r\n\t<li>Note that due to LDD&rsquo;s issue with colouring the recently added dual-molded leg piece, both Supergirl and Silver Banshee&rsquo;s legs in the final images have rendered incorrectly, and are unable to be fixed.&nbsp; Supergirl is intended to have Dark Stone Grey upper legs and hips (representing her tights) and New Dark Red lower legs for her boots.&nbsp; Silver Banshee has Black upper legs and hips, and White boots.</li>\r\n\t<li>Regardless of the eventual result and eligibility of my project, I hope that this design inspires others to create their own models and designs, be it for&nbsp;<em>Supergirl </em>or any other project they wish to design and hope to come to fruition.&nbsp; If there is sufficient demand, I will upload the .lxf file online and link in the description for those who wish to make their own modifications or physically build the model.</li>\r\n\t<li>I&rsquo;m still only fairly new to the program LDD to POV-Ray Converter in order to render the final images, so any suggestions to improve quality (especially lighting) are definitely appreciated.</li>\r\n\t<li>Comments, suggestions and questions are welcome!</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<ul>\r\n\t<li>Coming Soon...&nbsp;&nbsp;<em>The Flash</em>: <em>S.T.A.R. 10193 Medieval Market Village was a remarkably popular set. But I think it turned pretty good, and I hope you enjoy!</span></p>\r\n\r\n<p><span>This build is rougly 1000 pieces, was very difficult to make and will have 4 minifigs: 2 traveling soldiers, a farmer&#39;s son, and his younger brother.</span></p>\r\n\r\n<p>Please check out my other projects here:</p>\r\n\r\n<p><a href=\"http://ideas.lego.com/profile/TheLordOfBricks/projects\" target=\"_blank\">http://ideas.lego.com/profile/TheLordOfBricks/projects</a></p>\r\n\r\n<p>For more suggested profiles, please check out these pages:</p>\r\n\r\n<p><a href=\"http://ideas.lego.com/profile/theJman_bricks/projects\" target=\"_blank\">http://ideas.lego.com/profile/theJman_bricks/projects</a></p>\r\n\r\n<p><a href=\"http://ideas.lego.com/profile/Hawkibro123/projects\" target=\"_blank\">http://ideas.lego.com/profile/Hawkibro123/projects</a></p>\r\n\r\n<p><a href=\"http://ideas.lego.com/profile/Anduin1710/projects\" target=\"_blank\">http://ideas.lego.com/profile/Anduin1710/projects</a></p>\r\n\r\n<p><a href=\"http://ideas.lego.com/profile/RAKRONDEWL/projects\" target=\"_blank\">http://ideas.lego.com/profile/RAKRONDEWL/projects</a></p>\r\n\r\n<p><a href=\"http://ideas.lego.com/profile/Camshaft/projects\" target=\"_blank\">http://ideas.lego.com/profile/Camshaft/projects</a></p>\r\n\r\n<p><a href=\"http://ideas.lego.com/profile/StudTech/activity\" target=\"_blank\">http://ideas.lego.com/profile/StudTech/activity</a></p>\r\n\r\n<p><a href=\"http://ideas.lego.com/profile/LoneCoyote/activity\" target=\"_blank\">http://ideas.lego.com/profile/LoneCoyote/activity</a></p>\r\n\r\n<p><a href=\"http://ideas.lego.com/profile/JediPippin/projects\" target=\"_blank\">http://ideas.lego.com/profile/JediPippin/projects</a></p>\r\n\r\n<p><a href=\"http://ideas.lego.com/profile/TheLordOfBricks/projects\" target=\"_blank\">http://ideas.lego.com/profile/TheLordOfBricks/projects</a></p>\r\n\r\n<p>Thanks to everyone for supporting, following, commenting, and sharing! Antarctica was left out because they have no vehicles, and South America was left out due to not being able to find a reference photo. From left to right, there is a truck form Africa, a truck from North America, a truck from Asia, a truck from Australia, and a van from Europe. A few fellow Ideas members have been saying i only focus on US style builds. So that is how this creation all started. Fellow member Camshaft suggested this project as a solution. It can be quite educational for children too learn about other continents, countries, and cultures.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The African work truck is green with black accents and tow mirrors. It has yellow and black warning stripes on the front bumper. In the bed, there is a water tank designed by the great Lightningtiger. Big thanks to him. The interior is basic with two black seats, speedometers,steering wheel, and a completed dash. It also has right hand steering.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The North American work truck is red with light grey and black accents. It is a crew cab regular bed format. There is 4 black cupboards with grey doors and a ladder rack installed on the bed. The interior is basic with four black seats, a steering wheel, a set of speedometers, and a completed dash.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The Asian work truck is personally my favorite. It is yellow with black accents. It has a custom ladder rack mounted on the front and rear bumpers. The interior is really simple, with only a steering wheel, and no seats, but there will be an updated version soon. This model comes with right hand steering.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The Australian work truck is commonly called a Ute. It is white with black accents, and light grey bed. The front end was designed by LegoBricker. So big thanks to him. The bed has a ladder rack is &nbsp;installed into the bed. The rear bumper has a number plate on it. The interior is basic with two black seats, a steering wheel, a set of speedometers, and a completed dash. This truck also has right hand steering.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The European work van was suggested by fellow member CountBrickoski. It is a simple white panel van that is common in the Europe area. It is white with black accents and tow mirrors. The cabin doors and rear doors open. The van is in a medium length chassis with high roof set up. The interior has two black seats, a steering wheel, a set of speedometers, and a completed dash including one A/C vent. The cargo bay of the van has nothing in it. Tool boxes and other accessories can easily be added. On the roof, there is a ladder rack. This model features right hand steering.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>This set contains 726 bricks and would sell in the $75 to $100 US currency range. All models include ladders. an iconic model and&nbsp;a perfect example of signature Porsche style with curvy lines, round front lights and smooth body shape that no other car has. The choice to make exactly this model was inspired by the official set of Porsche GT3, but my way has been a bit different, as I wanted to make the car smaller. The final push for me to sit down and say &quot;yep, I want to build this&quot; was the contest, therefore I&nbsp;could make my plans come true and finally have a final decision to start with my Porsche.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>The model</strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p>My version of 911 is made in smaller scale compared to GT3 set - first of all, because I wanted to concentrate on details instead of size (this doesn&#39;t mean I&#39;m trying to criticize the set, it&#39;s amazing) and to be able to place the model on the shelf :P In further perspective, if the dream will come true and the set will be produced, it will be less expensive than GT3&nbsp;and therefore a bit more available for the ones who want to buy it.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The model features:</p>\r\n\r\n<ul>\r\n\t<li>5+R manual gearbox with controls inside the car;</li>\r\n\t<li>Steering system with functioning steering wheel;</li>\r\n\t<li>Fully independent suspension;</li>\r\n\t<li>Opening doors and adjustable seats.</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>Why this project?</strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p>The Porsche theme itself is interesting and could be not a single-set appearance but a small line&nbsp;of sets like the Technic / Volvo one. Exactly this model could be a smaller collectible set for those who can&#39;t afford the exclusive GT3 or simply want another Porsche on their shelf. NASA or the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Yet in many cases, their contributions are&nbsp;unknown or under-appreciated &mdash; especially as women have historically struggled to gain acceptance in the fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM).<br />\r\n&nbsp;</div>\r\nThis proposed set celebrates five notable NASA pioneers and provides an educational building experience to help young ones and adults alike learn about the history of women in STEM. The five Women of NASA are:<br />\r\n&nbsp;</div>\r\n<strong>Margaret Hamilton</strong>,<strong> </strong>computer scientist: While working at MIT under contract with NASA in the 1960s, Hamilton developed the on-board flight software for the Apollo missions to the moon. She is known for popularizing the modern concept of software.<br />\r\n&nbsp;</div>\r\n<strong>Katherine Johnson</strong>, mathematician and space scientist: A longtime NASA researcher, Johnson is best known for calculating and verifying trajectories for the Mercury and Apollo programs &mdash; including the Apollo 11 mission that first landed humans on the moon.<br />\r\n&nbsp;</div>\r\n<strong>Sally Ride</strong>, astronaut, physicist, and educator: A physicist by training, Ride became the first American woman in space in 1983. After retiring as a NASA astronaut, she founded an educational company focusing on encouraging children &mdash; especially girls &mdash; to pursue the sciences.<br />\r\n&nbsp;</div>\r\n<strong>Nancy Grace Roman</strong>, astronomer: One of the first female executives at NASA, Roman is known to many as the &quot;Mother of Hubble&quot; for her role in planning the Hubble Space Telescope. She also developed NASA&#39;s astronomy research program.<br />\r\n&nbsp;</div>\r\n<strong>Mae Jemison</strong>, astronaut, physician, and entrepreneur: Trained as a medical doctor, Jemison became the first African-American woman in space in 1992. After retiring from NASA, Jemison established a company that develops new technologies and encourages students in the sciences.<br />\r\n&nbsp;</div>\r\nIn addition to a desktop frame that displays these five minifigures and their names, the set includes vignettes depicting: a famous photo of the reams of code that landed astronauts on the moon in 1969; instruments used to calculate and verify trajectories for the Mercury and Apollo missions; a microscale Hubble Space Telescope and display; and a mini space shuttle, complete with external tank and solid rocket boosters.</div>\r\n\r\n<div>&nbsp;</div>\r\n\r\n<div>Thanks in advance for your support! NY", "state": {"name_short": "Gathering Support", "alias": "gathering_support"}, "stats_views_count": 234, "body": "<p>Open one of the images above and keep clicking on it to see a 360&ordm; view of the model.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Designed by Phillip Johnson and built for the 1964 World&#39;s Fair, the Astro-View Observation Towers were part of the New York State Pavilion. The three concrete towers are 226 feet (69 m), 160 feet (49 m) and&nbsp; 85 feet (26 m) high. On the outside of the tallest column there are two elevators called Sky Streaks which transported people from the ground the 64 foot (19.5 m) diameter observation platforms. One Sky Streak served the lower two platforms, and a second served the double platform on the third column.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>According to Philip Johnson, the Observation Towers were not part of his original design but added after Governor Rockefeller insisted that the New York State Pavilion be the tallest structure at the Fair. The taller platforms <span>gave fantasic views of all the Pavilions of the World&#39;s Fair, the Unisphere which is a 140 foot tall stainless-steel globe and uninterrupted views of the New York City Skyline.</span> The lowest platform was a snack bar.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Although all of the structures at the World&#39;s Fair were supposed to be temporary the Govenor paid for the tower&#39;s foundations to be permanent. However, at the close of the Fair in 1965 the towers were closed and have stood unused ever since.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The model used 163 pieces, and makes up into a size which fits with the mainstream Architecture range. It has been designed using LDD and I have used the option to use parts in colours which are not currently available for the elevator and roof of each tower.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The most difficult part off the design was the Sky Streak Cables at the rear of the tall tower. I would expect these to be made by cutting the flexible tube to length (which is something LEGO have done with their official sets) however, I did manage to make them up using standard parts - even if it did mean using a couple of minifigure &#39;lipsticks&#39;!</p>\r\n\r\n<p>If you like this Architecture set then please support and let your friends know about it too.</p>\r\n", "user_comments_locked": false, "tags": ["Fair", "Saucer", "observation towers", "astro-view", "sky-streak", "1964", "new york", "USA"], "state_entered_at": "2016-07-14T16:37:17.000Z", "user": {"alias": "Eiffleman", "id": 859077, "uuid": "f6cc0079-5c7d-4086-9816-09da85d0de58"}, "product_image_url": null, "stats_followers_count_short": "19", "price_usd": null, "product_id": null, "stats_supporters_count_short": "52", "support_ending_at": "2017-07-14T16:37:17.000Z", "product_description": null, "published_at_formatted": "Jul 14, 2016", "image_url": "https://dp1eoqdp1qht7.cloudfront.net/community/projects/d75/b42/147281/2556769-o_1anj0lms76rqjlerbu1hno1r11e-full.jpg", "state_id": 149, "stats_comments_count": 19, "stats_views_count_short": "234"}, {"stats_days_left": 350.91756537818287, "updated_at": "2016-07-28T06:05:12.000Z", "image_tile_url": "https://dp1eoqdp1qht7.cloudfront.net/community/projects/42a/ec6/147534/2556433-o_1animiqqebuirfj0l1t21974g-thumbnail-uBPbLZX5ECsHpQ.jpeg", "stats_supporters_count": 13, "published_at": "2016-07-14T15:59:16.000Z", "sold_out": null, "stats_followers_count": 10, "stats_comments_count_short": "14", "id": 147534, "user_id": 1109902, "uuid": "e7ea3130-5a9f-435a-b91c-0c16c45f8082", "product_image_tile_url": null, "title": "Lava Throne", "state": {"name_short": "Gathering Support", "alias": "gathering_support"}, "stats_views_count": 175, "body": "<p>Do you know any king of&nbsp;lava, is he real? Probes, shuttles, satellites etc. Lego sets have been produced of ships and probes, however we don`t see how these probes were launched. This set changes that, with a focus on the launcher&nbsp;instead of the probe itself.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><span>The power source is a special crystal with enough power to last the launcher for a year. The crystals are mined from the mountains by a miner. A scientist then inserts it into the generator, and it starts to suck the power from it. project, let&rsquo;s talk about the original model and its designer.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>Ludovic Lazareth</strong> is a French talented designer. His company (&ldquo;<strong>Lazareth</strong>&rdquo;) is based in Annecy, a beautiful little town located in the French Alps.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>One of his last creation is called <strong>LM 847</strong> &hellip; If I had to chose just two words to describe Ludovic Lazareth&rsquo;s LM 847, I would probably say &ldquo;<em><strong>Beautiful Beast</strong></em>&rdquo;. LM 847 is indeed a motorcycle (yes it is !) with four independent wheels and powered by the 4.7-liter, 32-valve V8 Maserati engine !! This amazing engine unleaches no less than 470 horsepower &hellip; that&rsquo;s probably the reason why Ludovic Lazareth made the choice to transplant two huge tires on the back of his LM 847. Each rear wheel is connected to the Maserati engine and is suspended independently.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Thanks to this complex system, when one wheel moves up, the other one moves down, and this allows the bike to lean &hellip;</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The same two tires are found at the front end but this time the system is more complex. Indeed, as for the rear part, the two wheels have to move independently and must also include the steering system !!</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Between the front and rear wheels, the monstrous engine, a wide handlebar and a tail section sampled from a Ducati Panigale &hellip;</p>\r\n\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p>This &ldquo;bike&rdquo; is just amazing and I decided to build a LEGO version about three months ago !</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Understanding how the front and rear suspensions worked and building this set with features as close as possible to the real LM 847 <strong>was a big challenge !</strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p>Finally, three months later, here is my LM 847 :</p>\r\n\r\n<ul>\r\n\t<li>V8 working engine connected to the two independent rear wheels</li>\r\n\t<li>Front and rear tilting 2-wheel suspension</li>\r\n\t<li>Working steering system consisting of no less than 21 gear wheels</li>\r\n\t<li>Two independent front body panels</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n\r\n<p>I also built a bike lift tailored to the specific features of the LM 847. This <strong>fully working</strong> model is based of the Chinese version of the abacus called the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suanpan\">Suanpan</a>. I chose the Suanpan over other configurations of the abacus because it is fairly simple to build and use and can do many complex calculations very efficiently. In addition to the four basic operations (add, subtract, divide, multiply) the Suanpan also can efficiently calculate square and cube roots.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The Suanpan has an upper row with two beads on each column. These upper beads represent 5 of the lower beads. The units (or &#39;ones&#39;) column is on the right, and each column to the left represents an additional order of magnitude (10, 100, 1000, etc.)&nbsp;You can see a basic&nbsp;demonstration of how to use an abacus here:&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CvsnftXXKdw\">here</a>.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>I think the Abacus would make a great desk toy for an adult and a great teaching tool for a child just beginning to learn arithmetic. Children can connect with their parents daily lives when they leave and parents can share their&nbsp;work&nbsp; lives or hobby with their children in play. This set is also designed around a female worker or hobbyist to illustrate the importance and ability of females in today&#39;s world.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>What better way to spark a child&#39;s interest in building a better future than to use play to explain the real world skills their parents use at work. Lamb</em> from the architectural firm Shreve, Lamb and Harmon, </span>the art deco styling of the Empire State Building is as an icon of New York City.</p>\r\n\r\n<ul>\r\n\t<li><strong>Construction Started: </strong>1929.</li>\r\n\t<li><strong>Construction Completed: </strong>1931.</li>\r\n\t<li><strong>Cost of Empire State Building:</strong>&nbsp;$40,948,900.</li>\r\n\t<li><strong>Empire State Building Height:</strong> 1,250 ft. to roof / 1,454 ft. to top of antenna spire (added 1951).</li>\r\n\t<li><strong>Number of Stories in Empire State Building</strong>: 102.</li>\r\n</ul>\r\n\r\n<p>The model is made from <strong>1040</strong> LEGO pieces and stands <strong>46 cm</strong> tall. This model is significantly larger than the previous versions offered in the Architecture range, but not so big that it could not be an official set. Of the 1040 pieces 464 are the small 1x2 radiator grilles which make up the vertical line features on the exterior of the building.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><em><strong>Empire State Building Fact:</strong> The Empire State Building was the tallest building in New York City for 40 consecutive years, from 1931 until 1972.</em></p>\r\n\r\n<p>As it can sometimes be difficult&nbsp;to judge the overall size of a model I have included a image of my Empire State Building next to the latest LEGO version - from the New York City set (21028) and the Eiffel Tower (21019). (King Kong minifigure&nbsp;being buzzed by biplanes is just for fun.)</p>\r\n\r\n<p><em><strong>Empire State Building Fact:</strong> The 200 foot mast was added during the build as a mooring post to allow airships to dock in the city - although none ever did. (but this did make the building taller than the Chrysler building).</em></p>\r\n\r\n<p>I have always felt that the Empire State Building deserved a larger scale model, but it was making the New York City set and seeing the strong vertical lines that the radiator grille pieces created in it that really got the project rolling. There were several challenges in making all the various rectangular exterior blocks join together seemlessly and the observation deck proved quite difficult to to create the small steps and still have studs on the sides to hold all the exterior cladding in place.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>I think this would make a great set which would appeal to fans of the Architecture range, fans of the building&nbsp;and "<p>\u4e00\u3001</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The T-rex is the apex predator in the Cretaceous age, and the most perfect masterpiece evolution has ever managed to accomplish. Because 65 million years after its extinction, it is still the biggest and most powerful carnivore ever walked the earth.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>When I first watch&nbsp;<em>Jurassic Park</em>, I was immediately captivated by the power and beauty of the T-rex, and hopelessly fell in love with her. And what beats watching a T-rex movie? Building one yourself! At 59 cm length and 930 grams weight, This model is possibly the world*&rsquo;s&nbsp;<strong>largest</strong>&nbsp;posable T-rex that stands on its own. * LEGO world :-)</p>\r\n\r\n<p>If you&nbsp;like it, and want to build one yourself, pleas&nbsp;<strong>support</strong>&nbsp;me :-)&nbsp;&nbsp;A thousand&nbsp;<strong>thanks</strong>.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>\u4e8c\u3001Features:</p>\r\n\r\n<p>1. It grew bigger as the building went on, for we are all greedy in the detail department. As a result, at a certain moment, It suddenly hit me that this thing may never&nbsp;be able to stand on its own when finished, and that would be an ultimate bummer (Yes, it&rsquo;s my second MOC, I never knew LEGO was so heavy!). But due to a&nbsp;technique (mixel joints served as tendons), a lot of time and effort put into banlancing, and many compromises made to aesthetics, the completed T-rex&nbsp;<strong>stands on its own</strong>. (It may not pose a problem for digital building, but I consider this the No.1 feature of this build.)</p>\r\n\r\n<p>2. Play features: This beast is not only a display piece, It is moderately&nbsp;<strong>posable</strong>&nbsp;thanks to a lot of joints. And it has to be from the conveiving because there are so many cool postures and it would be a waste of bricks if it ends up to be just a statue. Again, aesthetics has to give way&hellip; to gaps. But the very essence of LEGO saves the day again: with a few parts (modules) added or removed, the gaps left by maneuvers can be covered.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>3.&nbsp;<strong>Sturdy</strong>.&nbsp;Every time I had to choose between appearance and sturdiness, I chose the latter, for which I think is a virtue of official sets.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>4. I try to get the&nbsp;proportions&nbsp;as&nbsp;<strong>real</strong>&nbsp;as possible.&nbsp;Oftentimes I see a T-rex MOC, the head is over-sized to stress the beast&#39;s ferociousness and the feet are disproportionately&nbsp;large to increase stability.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>5.&nbsp;<strong>Stud-Not-On-Top</strong>&nbsp;design, and all&nbsp;&ldquo;<strong>legal</strong>&rdquo; LEGO parts and techniques.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>For more Hi-Def&nbsp;pics go to&nbsp;<a href=\"https://flic.kr/s/aHskCpW3Se\">https://flic.kr/s/aHskCpW3Se</a></p>\r\n\r\n<p>\u4e09\u3001</p>\r\n\r\n<p><span>\u5982\u679c\u4f60\u559c\u6b22\u8fd9\u4e2a\u9738\u738b\u9f99\uff0c\u800c\u4e14\u8fd8\u80fd\u770b\u61c2\u6c49\u5b57\uff0c\u5c31\u66f4\u5f97\u652f\u6301\u6211\u5566\uff01\u8c22\u8c22\uff01:-)</span></p>\r\n\r\n<p>Thank you.</p>\r\n", "user_comments_locked": false, "tags": ["Jurassic", "Cretaceous", "creature", "animal", "tyrannosaurus", "t-rex", "triceratops", "Arctic", "dinosaur", "posable"], "state_entered_at": "2016-07-06T06:40:16.000Z", "user": {"alias": "Gezheng Qu", "id": 961728, "uuid": "cdc79457-d65e-48b6-afc1-1db5ab84e490"}, "product_image_url": null, "stats_followers_count_short": "35", "price_usd": null, "product_id": null, "stats_supporters_count_short": "175", "support_ending_at": "2017-07-06T06:40:16.000Z", "product_description": null, "published_at_formatted": "Jul 06, 2016", "image_url": "https://dp1eoqdp1qht7.cloudfront.net/community/projects/56f/1b3/146539/2540779-o_1amqq2mvc1rkt1dfnthg7f6aas7-full.jpg", "state_id": 149, "stats_comments_count": 48, "stats_views_count_short": "967"}, {"stats_days_left": 342.52406712733796, "updated_at": "2016-07-28T06:05:11.000Z", "image_tile_url": "https://dp1eoqdp1qht7.cloudfront.net/community/projects/bcf/637/146517/2543274-o_1amtvgoopfkv1rkb15u01klk1f2d7-thumbnail-JN0TGWKCvL_8Bg.png", "stats_supporters_count": 33, "published_at": "2016-07-06T06:32:40.000Z", "sold_out": null, "stats_followers_count": 14, "stats_comments_count_short": "28", "id": 146517, "user_id": 1010810, "uuid": "840edf9c-70da-4ab5-a69a-91fb1e2bf631", "product_image_tile_url": null, "title": "Apple Watch", "state": {"name_short": "Gathering Support", "alias": "gathering_support"}, "stats_views_count": 266, "body": "<p>Hey guys!!! The basic&nbsp;idea of the show consists of amateur chefs selected from across the country who compete in various cooking challenges. Celebrity chef judges critique the contestants&#39; dishes, and contestants are successively eliminated until&nbsp;one is crowned winner and awarded a MasterChef trophy. MasterChef is currently produced in over 45 countries around the world, including the United States, Canada, Australia, Brazil, China, France, Germany, South Africa, Italy, Portugal, Spain, South Korea, and Turkey.<br />\r\n<br />\r\nThe present project is inspired by the original U.S. Version of the show, featuring celebrity chef judge Gordon Ramsay.<br />\r\n<br />\r\nPlease check out some of my other projects!<br />\r\nVintage Tram https://ideas.lego.com/projects/119603<br />\r\nSan Francisco Cable Car https://ideas.lego.com/projects/125350<br />\r\n<br />\r\n<strong>DESCRIPTION</strong><br />\r\n<br />\r\nBuilt using LEGO Digital Designer, this project is divided into 3 main modules: the kitchen, the stage, and the pantry.<br />\r\n<br />\r\n<strong>Kitchen</strong>&nbsp;(206 pieces)<br />\r\n<br />\r\nThe kitchen module is where contestants feverishly prepare their concoctions to try to impress the judges. It features a total of six stations, divided into three rows of two. Each station includes a cooktop, oven, drawer, counter with cutting board, storage space, as well as a shared sink. The front row also showcases&nbsp;a backlit &quot;MasterChef&quot; signage.<br />\r\n<br />\r\n<strong>Stage</strong> (94 pieces)<br />\r\n<br />\r\nThe stage module is where the judges&nbsp;preside for much of the show, are where contestants present their dishes to be critiqued. It features a raised platform with a back glass wall. Both showcase the MasterChef logo.<br />\r\n<br />\r\n<strong>Pantry</strong> (413 pieces)<br />\r\n<br />\r\nThe well-stocked pantry module is where contestants pick and gather&nbsp;their ingredients for their creations. It features a centre station full of various fruits and vegetables, as&nbsp;well as a selection of fresh herbs. Along the side wall&nbsp;are&nbsp;two shelves full of sauces, spices,&nbsp;and other useful ingredients. Lastly, along the back wall is a table of&nbsp;breads, a large refrigerator, as well as MasterChef logo.<br />\r\n<br />\r\n<strong>Minifigs</strong><br />\r\n<br />\r\nThe judge minifigs are based on the celebrity&nbsp;TV personalities featured in the original U.S. version of the show, namely Gordon Ramsay, Graham Elliot, and Joe Bastianich. All&nbsp;have custom torsos and faces&nbsp;to reflect their trademark look and style of attire. The contestants, meanwhile,&nbsp;are wearing the MasterChef&nbsp;apron represented by custom torsos and leg prints.<br />\r\n<br />\r\nComments, questions, and constructive feedback of this model is It is roughly based on the 2009 Ford F-250 Utility bed. it is a white two door long bed version. Under the hood is a powerful diesel engine to tow whatever trailer you need to get the job done. Sadly forgot the hitch, but watch for it in an update. The front end stays really close to the original F-250 look. The cab is&nbsp;really basic with dark grey seats, and black accessories. There are also black tow mirrors. The bed is&nbsp;mainly basic with only 4 built in tool boxes. Two of which have drawers to sort your tools, and two regular storage bins. There is a ladder rack mounted a top the utility bed with an extension ladder, and an orange strobe light. There are two taillight and two turn signals mounted on the bed. There is also room in between the two tool boxes to haul materials for your job from a 2x4 plate to a 1x16 brick, the&nbsp;possibilities are endless! They have seen the construction vehicles working in the area, but now the attraction&nbsp;is ready for operation!</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The visitors have started to complain about some facilities they think are missing. The Theme Park administration are&nbsp;listening and&nbsp;will try to solve the problems in the near future.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Some facts about the Ferris Wheel. The wheel measures 51 studs in height which IRL would be approximately 30 meters, and is built up from 572 pieces.&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p>* * *</p>\r\n\r\n<p>I have always enjoyed the magic of theme parks and loved the different rides. Now I have combined this pleasure with my passion of LEGO construction in a project.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>I have used microscale to reduce the number of bricks needed, and to have a greater challenge in the designing process. It is&nbsp;fun to build different rides with just a&nbsp;small&nbsp;amount of bricks.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>All the sets are constructed on 16x16 base plates which you can snap&nbsp;together to create a large Theme Park. The&nbsp;base plates&nbsp;can easily be parted&nbsp;again and reshuffled to create a new park.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>I have added a picture with Theme Park units&nbsp;put together, so you can see an example of a Theme Park. "<p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>Please support this project if you would like to have one on your bookshelf! Thanks!</strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p>\u3010Ray&#39;s Lego Bus Model Workshop\u3011#16101824</p>\r\n\r\n<p>My &ldquo;world of the buses&rdquo; collection has a new member, the typical <strong>American School Bus.</strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p><em><strong>[Background]</strong></em></p>\r\n\r\n<p>Needless to say, this is one of the most common seen school bus among the US territory. Every morning and evening, these big and sturdy vehicles carries thousands of kids to and back from school, supporting the traffic of the youth. They are so iconic, that once you see these yellow machines, you know that they are not just ordinary buses.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong><em>[Design of the model]</em></strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p>The design took several month total to complete. We are trying to build it as resemblance to a real one as possible. We did a lot of the real dimension to scale analysis, and decided to make one that is the same scale as minifigures, (thus could go along) and as accurate as possible. Moreover, there are several tough points, different from regular buses, such as stop signs working arm, curved top, narrow working doors etc. (so many fun parts!)</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Luckily they all came along with the new fantastic model.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong><em>Key part, the working stop sign:</em></strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p>To design the working stop sign takes a long time. We tried most of the designs, but it turns out that they may stands out from the outer shell too far and thus not realistic. We want a design that when the sign withdraws it merged to the outer shell as close as possible, like the real bus, that&rsquo;s why we finally chose this new design of the stop sign. Please see pictures for details.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><em><strong>[Model Details]</strong></em></p>\r\n\r\n<p>This model comes with the authentic outlook, any memories from the past?</p>\r\n\r\n<p>(Sadly, more than half of them are already retired, becoming part of our precious childhood moments, that&rsquo;s why with your support this could be one that stands on your book shelf to refresh your memories!)</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>The details:</strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p>-Iconic Front</p>\r\n\r\n<p>-Outside details, windows (see them open?)</p>\r\n\r\n<p>-Real Engine compartment</p>\r\n\r\n<p>-Side storage compartment (6 big and 1 small, and we have put something useful inside)</p>\r\n\r\n<p>-Windows and doors</p>\r\n\r\n<p>-Extra mirror details</p>\r\n\r\n<p>-Special stop lights</p>\r\n\r\n<p>-Authentic interior details</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Etc.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>(Play with) Moving parts:</strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p>-Adjustable mirrors,</p>\r\n\r\n<p>-Front safety shield/bar</p>\r\n\r\n<p>-Emergency exits open (both sides)</p>\r\n\r\n<p>-Luggage compartment opens \uff08there are 7! \uff09</p>\r\n\r\n<p>-Front door opens as real bus</p>\r\n\r\n<p>-Real engine compartment opens! This is my creation for a future oriented bike service. Electric bikes to move faster and in a cleaner way through our Lego city and a confortable service for all Lego citizen: Bike Sharing.</div>\r\n\r\n<div>\r\n<div>&nbsp;</div>\r\n\r\n<div><strong>Electric bike sharing</strong></div>\r\n\r\n<div>The station is composed by various docks where Lego citizens can pick up or park the electric bikes. White docks are the point where you can pick up the bike. Bikes can be perfectly inserted inside docks. If you have a green light the bike battery charging is complete, so you have a full electric autonomy (30 kilometers more or less). If the light is red the dock is empty (no bike) or charging is not complete. It&#39;ll be a funny game to substitute green or red lights when a new bike is fully charged or simply attached to the dock. In any case electric bikes are easy to boost by your legs, like any other bike. But in this way electric power will help you, you&#39;ll move faster and you&#39;ll save part of your energy.&nbsp; How to use it? Bike sharing always move from one point to another (from A to B): imagine you have a big Lego city, you can buy one or more Bike sharing sets, mount the docks in any part of the city you prefer (the docks are modular) and so the user will pick up the electric bike in point A of the city and will park it in point B.&nbsp;</div>\r\n\r\n<div>&nbsp;</div>\r\n\r\n<div><strong>A nice place</strong></div>\r\n\r\n<div>In our cities bike sharing docks are often along roads or in similar places. In this case I created a garden around the station, some LED street lamps to light the station during the night, and a fountain to recover fresh water during the hot season. Usually bike sharing&nbsp;provide all white, or all blue, or all red bikes:&nbsp;in my case all bikes are differently coloured.&nbsp;&nbsp;A nice place to stop, a nice place to start from!</div>\r\n\r\n<div>&nbsp;</div>\r\n\r\n<div><strong>The cycling road</strong></div>\r\n\r\n<div>The entire station has a cycling road inside, red coloured, that will reconnect to cycling lanes in our Lego city.&nbsp;</div>\r\n\r\n<div>&nbsp;</div>\r\n\r\n<div>There are many things inside this creation, I&#39;ll surely update this idea during next week focusing on some particulars. Its artwork and spacing combine to create comport, ease, joy and love.&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p>&nbsp; This 19th century&rsquo;s construction styled white building may perfectly comport with your modular, and its architecture and surroundings provide the beauty of art. I tried to put traditional architectural factors established in 19th through the exterior. Renovations with modern techniques like huge metal sign with printed letters and big strong glass panels are integrated without incongruities with old fashion.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>&nbsp; Foods and entertainments are waiting here for you and your mini figures. Think of yourself being a traveler with a camera in one hand, brand new straw hat on your back, and having a brunch in MJC&#39;s. You will find yourself packing a trunk tonight to leave for somewhere in the morning.&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>Features</strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p>&nbsp; The MJC&rsquo;s serves a casual lunch and dinner with fresh meat and vegetables everyday. A kitchen is filled with stoves, a big glossy cooking table, and lots of pans and dishes. Big glass panels are installed on the wall to enable customers to appreciate chef&rsquo;s skillful cooking. A hidden basement has been storing bottles of sweet ice wines from the town vineyard since last winter. If you have a bite of the testers at the food stand on the road and check out menu list, you cannot help coming inside to order your lunch.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>&nbsp; Party room on the second floor is opened for any communities. Gather for social networking, birthday party and any special moments with your friends. Please contact right now to book the place! A wide comfortable sofa, a mini figure sized grand piano, sitting chairs, a food table, an antique wind cellar are available to use for free. &nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p>&nbsp; The third floor is a lounge with an observatory. You cannot miss beautiful scenes of downtown through the telescope. A bending machine is ready to supply casual drinks for thirsty tourists. Part of this floor is the space for the owner of the building. The room is used as an office and living space for him.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>&nbsp; The rooftop is a young artist&rsquo;s studio. It is constructed with over 900 bricks, and is 23.6 studs x 33 1/6 studs x 9 1/6 bricks, and weighs only 1.46 lbs. The laptop&#39;s hinges are built just right, so that there&#39;s enough friction to keep the laptop closed or open, but not too much so that it&#39;s easy to open, revealing the features inside. The fully customizable screen has plenty of space to build whatever images you want, the printed and custom-colored keys are actually pressable (via the incredibly clever use of rubber bands), the mousepad has two buttons and a scroll bar, there are two speakers, and 7 extra buttons toward the top. On the outside, you can place the included brick-built thumbdrive in the snap-in USB ports, or place your headphone connection in either of the headphone jacks.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The model is full of tricky techniques and building styles that could put any builder to the test. and&nbsp;</span><em>pteron</em><span>&nbsp;&quot;wing&quot;) is an&nbsp;</span>aircraft<span>&nbsp;that&nbsp;</span>flies<span>&nbsp;by flapping its&nbsp;</span>wings<span>. Designers seek to imitate the flapping-wing flight of birds,&nbsp;</span>bats<span>, and&nbsp;</span>insects<span>. Though machines may differ in form, they are usually built on the same&nbsp;</span>scale<span>&nbsp;as these flying creatures. Manned ornithopters have also been built, and some have been successful. The machines are of two general types: those with engines, and those powered by the&nbsp;</span>muscles<span>&nbsp;of the&nbsp;</span>pilot<span>. "product_image_tile_url": null, "title": "Ornithopter", "state": {"name_short": "Gathering Support", "alias": "gathering_support"}, "stats_views_count": 660, "body": "<p lang=\"en-US\">ORNITHOPTER</p>\r\n\r\n<p lang=\"en-US\">It is no surprise that humanity&rsquo;s first attempts at flight were in the form of birdlike, human-powered ornithopters. The great artist and engineer Leonardo Da Vinci is often credited as the first to propose a reasonable flying machine in 1490: a giant bat-shaped craft that uses both the pilot&rsquo;s arms and legs to power the wings. Though the aircraft was never built, and we now know that it would not have flown, it was a remarkable achievement considering the knowledge of the day. At the turn of the 20th century, focus shifted both in the method of thrust production, from flapping wings to the propeller, and the method of power generation, from the human body to the internal combustion engine. With the aerodynamic problem greatly simplified, the impossibility of human flight was disproved by the Wright brother&rsquo;s flight in 1903 and the stage was set for the boom of aircraft developments in the decades to come. Though work on human-powered aircraft was still carried on from time to time by several groups in various countries, it would be three-quarters of a century before anyone mastered the art of human-powered flight.</p>\r\n\r\n<p lang=\"en-US\">This LEGO set is a free interpretation based in the Leonardo&#39;s ornithopter. The flapping wings are full functional and are driven by a lever that also drives the pedaling block. The tail design includes a heavy handle avoiding structural flexing when the lever is turned.<br />\r\n<br />\r\nHere&nbsp; you can see a short video of flapping wings:<br />\r\n<br The most famous missions were the Apollo 11 (first manned&nbsp;moonlanding) and Apollo 13 (that inspired the movie starring by Tom Hanks).</p>\r\n\r\n<p><img src=\"https://dp1eoqdp1qht7.cloudfront.net/community/projects/86a/7be/140420/2514823-o_1all3lcmcojhhe11nkjg06eqc10.jpeg\" /></p>\r\n\r\n<p>This LEGO project includes:</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>Apollo Spacecraft Command and Service Module (Apollo CSM)</strong>. The model can be separated into its command module and the service module.&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The Command module has a hatch (that&nbsp;can be opened) and fits 3 astronauts inside (included).</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The CSM comes with&nbsp;a&nbsp;stand that fits the spacecraft.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><img src=\"https://dp1eoqdp1qht7.cloudfront.net/community/projects/86a/7be/140420/2514820-o_1all3lcmbm9184q76t19l2muvv-full.jpeg\" /><img src=\"https://dp1eoqdp1qht7.cloudfront.net/community/projects/86a/7be/140420/2513305-o_1alilm9j7nkl1trl5n9rip1p2j19-full.jpeg\" /></p>\r\n\r\n<p><img src=\"https://dp1eoqdp1qht7.cloudfront.net/community/projects/86a/7be/140420/2514817-o_1all3lcmbbd1jgg1ujjd2khptu.jpeg\" /></p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>Lunar Module</strong>. This is the spacecraft used for the moon landing. It can be separated in the ascent module (upper part) and descent module (lower part). The ascent module can be opened and fits two astronauts.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><img src=\"https://dp1eoqdp1qht7.cloudfront.net/community/projects/86a/7be/140420/2513311-o_1alilm9j7135kg8nks01u1v1s851b-full.jpeg\" /><img src=\"https://dp1eoqdp1qht7.cloudfront.net/community/projects/86a/7be/140420/2513317-o_1alilm9j7ego11eb1bn115ivuqs1d-full.jpeg\" /></p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>Lunar Roving Vehicle</strong>.<span>It&nbsp;was an electric-powered vehicle&nbsp;designed to operate in the low gravity of the Moon, and allowed the Apollo astronauts to extend the range of their surface extravehicular explorations. The LRV was&nbsp;populary known as the &quot;moon buggy&quot;. &nbsp;Three LRVs were driven in the Moon: in the Apollo 15 mission during 1971, and Apollo 16 and Apollo 17 during 1972.</span></p>\r\n\r\n<p><img src=\"https://dp1eoqdp1qht7.cloudfront.net/community/projects/86a/7be/140420/2513320-o_1alilm9j7kiombc3ihtb10pm1e-full.jpeg\" /></p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>Astronauts</strong>. Each Apollo Mission had a crew of three astronauts: Commander (orange strips in the spacesuit), LM pilot and CSM pilot. Only the Commander and the LM pilot did the moonlanding, while the CSM pilot stayed in the Apollo spacecraft orbiting the moon.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><img src=\"https://dp1eoqdp1qht7.cloudfront.net/community/projects/86a/7be/140420/2514814-o_1all3lcmb1o7mu3qmi6dco1dsht-full.jpeg\" /></p>\r\n\r\n<p>You can find more pictures in my flickr album:</p>\r\n\r\n<p>https://flic.kr/s/aHskCBsRUD</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Total pieces count: around 1200 pcs</p>\r\n\r\n<p>I think that the Apollo Program was one&nbsp;of the greatest milestones in the history of space exploration and a great moment in the history of mankind, so this project has great educational value for children and adults and would be of great interest to LEGO&nbsp;fans, especially those who have a special interest in space exploration and spacecraft.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>More information about the Apollo Program:&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollo_program</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The Saturn V rocket is not included in my project, because there is an amazing Saturn V project approved in LEGO Ideas&nbsp;(Apollo 11 - Saturn V by saabfan and whatsuptoday,&nbsp;https://ideas.lego.com/projects/76841&nbsp;)</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>Thanks for your support!</strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p>This project could become an official Lego set if it gathers 10,000 votes. Voting is easy, free and without any obligation, you just have to press the blue button &quot;Support&quot;. Many goods depots operated throughout the night which required an appropriate level of lighting across the working areas.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>This model is fitted with the Lego Technic Power Functions lighting system consisting of Battery Pack M8881, several LED M8870 and Extension Cable M8871 packs. The depot has external lighting in the form of simulated floodlighting on both the railway platform side and lorry loading bay side, and internal lighting to simulate the general illumination associated with ceiling lights. The roof of the depot has transparent sky lights which also emit light in the dark in a similar manner to the real thing. Several pictures have been taken in a low background light condition to show the effectiveness of the depot lighting.&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Although the model shown here includes several examples of the Scammell Scarab delivery vehicle, any of the existing Lego City delivery vehicles will work just as well. Similarly, the workmen figures could easily be replaced with a Lego Mini Figure set if required. Also shown is a drop side railway goods wagon which may be integrated with any of the existing Lego railway goods wagons.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The basic goods depot includes the loading/unloading bay, an office building with opening doors and outside lighting and an additional store house to disguise the M8881 battery box (the battery box switch is accessed through the blue doors, and battery box removal is via a rear door). Although disguising the battery box as a store house does make the model look a bit more realistic, it may be omitted to simplify things and keep the cost down. Also included are two short lengths of railway track and two buffer stops with illuminated red stop lamps (M8870).</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>The appeal</strong><br />\r\nThe overall aim of this set is to produce a model of a typical railway goods depot that may be produced as one large set including road and rail vehicles, and with a full lighting kit as shown here, or as several smaller sets building up into the full set.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>This model set is intended to be sufficiently accurate to appeal to the older collector and young builder. This tool was invented by Charles Brady King and helps to brake up asphalt concrete and so forth. Compressor from this set copies a real one from 1930&#39;s photo.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>How does it work? Lets ask Chris Woodford and Explainthatstaff. com :</p>\r\n\r\n<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &quot;In fact, the only energy involved in making a jackhammer pound up and down is supplied from an air hose. The hose, which has to be made of especially thick plastic, carries high-pressure air (typically 10 times higher pressure than the air around us) from a separate air-compressor unit powered by a diesel engine. The air compressor is a bit like a giant bicycle pump that never stops blowing air. When the worker presses down on the handle, air pumps from the compressor into the jackhammer through a valve on one side. Inside the hammer, there&#39;s a circuit of air tubes, a heavy piledriver, and a drill bit at the bottom. First, the high-pressure air flows one way round the circuit, forcing the piledriver down so it pounds into the drill bit, smashing it into the ground. A valve inside the tube network then flips over, causing the air to circulate in the opposite direction. Now the piledriver moves back upward, so the drill bit relaxes from the ground. A short time later, the valve flips over again and the whole process repeats&quot;</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Must have for any Lego City road repairing team!</p>\r\n\r\n<p>P.S. Don&#39;t miss this one - https://ideas.lego.com/projects/83275</p>\r\n", "user_comments_locked": false, "tags": ["road", "repair", "repairs", "lego", "city", "lego city", "jack hammer", "jackhammer", my project, Great White Shark. It is 17&#39;1/2 inches X 4 inches X 5 inches. This model took me 3 months to develop and its about 800-950 pieces. I took inspiration from the &quot;Lego Birds&quot; Ideas model set and wanted to make something related to an animal. So instead of a land animal I chose an underwater animal and that&#39;s where the Great White Shark came to mind.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>I wanted to add as much texture as i could to &quot;bring the model to life&quot; I added many slope pieces to create the body of the model. I also added Tiles in random spots to give the model a more rugged look. The black tiles near his snout represent gills for breathing underwater as well as a way to cover the insides of the model.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The fins of the model all are able to move except for the top fin because I wanted to put as much character into that fin as I could. For that fin I added More slope pieces as well as some studs for character and grill tiles to give it a tougher look.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>I tried my best to mix&nbsp;dark grey pieces and white pieces together because an actual great White Shark usuallyhas a darker top &nbsp;and a whiter bottom for his body. So, I blended the two colors together but also sometimes making the dark gray pieces go lower or the white pieces higher to give the shark a unique look and show that every shark is different in the way they look.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>I created a basic stand to hold the shark in place. It was mostly made of Technic pieces but also Lego Plates to hold the stand together. It was designed to have 6&nbsp;claws to grip the model in place&nbsp;and the two claws in the front of the stand have a Technic beam holding then together so the mouth of the model will be held in place.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Inside of the model&#39;s mouth, I created a imitation of the inside of the shark by using red plates and jumper pieces to look like the inside of the shark. For its head and eyes, I use two transparent yellow jumper plates to imitate eyes and used many different ways to create and develop the head of the shark.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Overall thank you for reading and looking at my model and imitation or the Great White Shark. It was built by Cisco and Harrison Wells into the remains of the old Particle Accelerator after it was damaged/destroyed by the explosion that caused&nbsp;Barry&nbsp;to become&nbsp;The Flash.<br />\r\nDesigned to hold highly dangerous Metahumans&nbsp;it is made up of numerous containments cells that can withstand and contain their powers, preventing even the likes of Barry from getting out.</strong></em><br />\r\n<br />\r\nThe set is built with two interchangeable containment cells which can slide on and off a holding platform behind the main door so you can swap between holding two villains, each cell has two levers on the side so that you can open/close the cell doors when its stationed.<br />\r\n<br />\r\nThe Main build is of the walkway which has its ramp with monitor and pipes&nbsp;running along the walls,&nbsp;and main door which you can slide up/down&nbsp;and keep held up with an arm at the back of the build, push down on&nbsp;lever&nbsp;to make the door drop shut.<br />\r\nIdeally I&#39;d like the door to have stickers that show the circular pattern as seen in the show (as shown in the images, unfortunately I haven&#39;t the IT skills to add it to the LDD image :p&nbsp;)<br />\r\n<br />\r\nWhile I appreciate there are a lot of characters people would like to see made into LEGO figures I&#39;ve again limited the figures to a realistic number and made the selection based on those who would fit the scene...<br />\r\n<br />\r\n<strong>The Flash</strong> - Barry needs to be included in any Flash set ;P<br />\r\n<br />\r\n<strong>Cisco Ramon</strong> - Creator/engineer of pretty much everything in STAR Labs, equipped with the Weather Wand he created to help stop Weather Wizard<br />\r\n<br />\r\n<strong>Joe West</strong> - Can&#39;t have a LEGO prison without a Cop... ;)<br />\r\nequipped with &quot;The Boot&quot;, a gun designed by Cisco to help&nbsp;capture meta humans<br />\r\n<br />\r\n<strong>Weather Wizard</strong>&nbsp;- One of the first villains held in the cells due to his ability to control/create the weather, such as his Ice/Hail balls which he can form in his hands to throw at his enemies.<br />\r\n<br />\r\n<strong>Piped Piper</strong> - (<em>aka Hartley Rathaway</em>) Equipped with gauntlets capable of&nbsp;emitting deafening&nbsp;sonic vibrations,&nbsp;Originally a member of S.T.A.R. Labs he was against Harrison Wells&nbsp;using the Particle Accelerator&nbsp;and developed a&nbsp;rivalry with Cisco&nbsp;<br />\r\n<br />\r\n<strong>Captain Cold</strong> - (<em>aka Leonard Snart</em>) While never really held in the Pipeline,&nbsp;Snart&nbsp;did double cross Team Flash in releasing all the meta humans that were being held towards the end of season 1<br />\r\n<br They had 21 seats distributed 2 + 1, with wooden seats. Had only a side door on the right side driven by the brakeman.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The Tram 373 is known as &quot;PiPi&quot;. This term was given by his usual passengers and stems from its bold design for the time by the usual passenger</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The main features stand out two General Electric engines (GE) 270 55HP (Horses Steam) and combiners General Electric (GE) B54E.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>It was not easy to get information about it, because it no longer circulates in my city for many years.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>The Concept </strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p>The great challenge in its construction in LEGO, was the front / rear, due to the angle that owned and roof also because of its angle.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>I used color &quot;Reddish Brown,&quot; because do not exist all the LEGO bricks, in the colors &quot;Medium Nougat&quot; or &quot;Dark Orange&quot;.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>There are endless topics to build with LEGO bricks. As such and not to get lost in this infinity, I chose vehicles and monuments, from the city of Porto (my city).</p>\r\n\r\n<p>This is another Tram, I think only exists in Portugal.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Apparently it seems to be easy to build in LEGO, but the biggest challenge are the angles of the front cabins / rear of this vehicle.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The front part is narrower than the area in which passengers traveling.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>About this project</strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p>This project consists of about 850 LEGO bricks.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>It was created in LDD, but was also built in parts, is about 40cm long.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>In my opinion, it is very cool, to build. Personally I have assembled and<br />\r\ndisassembled several times and consider it a very interesting model.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>In my LEGO creations, I always have in mind the consistency of the<br />\r\nassembly, so that the model does not dismount when we raise him in or when<br />\r\nwe touch him.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><a href=\"https://www.flickr.com/photos/134847396@N08/\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.flickr.com/photos/134847396@N08/</a></p>\r\n\r\n<p>&nbsp;I hope you enjoy this project.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><em>Thank you</em></p>\r\n\r\n<p><em>Miguel Rodrigues</em></p>\r\n", "user_comments_locked": false, "tags": ["Tram", "Transport", "Train", "Oporto City", "steampunk", "Electric cars"], "state_entered_at": "2016-06-20T06:36:07.000Z", "user": {"alias": "MikeCore", "id": 655712, "uuid": "50a5401e-4ee1-4af9-887c-df87945ac4e5"}, "product_image_url": null, "stats_followers_count_short": "27", "price_usd": null, "product_id": null, "stats_supporters_count_short": "91", "support_ending_at": "2017-06-20T06:36:07.000Z", "product_description": null, "published_at_formatted": "Jun 20, 2016", "image_url": "https://dp1eoqdp1qht7.cloudfront.net/community/projects/f99/cee/144791/2511758-o_1alfq3ke375vlcjen93r105q7-full.jpg", "state_id": 149, "stats_comments_count": 22, "stats_views_count_short": "371"}, {"stats_days_left": 326.5250709048264, "updated_at": "2016-07-28T06:05:07.000Z", "image_tile_url": "https://dp1eoqdp1qht7.cloudfront.net/community/projects/f08/6ba/144827/2512141-o_1alg8gff41lhfced1bo24nt11mrg-thumbnail-33H7CLnqlXQ4EQ.jpg", "stats_supporters_count": 19, "published_at": "2016-06-20T06:34:11.000Z", "sold_out": null, "stats_followers_count": 12, "stats_comments_count_short": "40", "id": 144827, "user_id": 1097875, "uuid": "28b93b60-67f4-41ee-a416-f25354b946e7", "product_image_tile_url": null, "title": "Superman Emblem", "state": {"name_short": "Gathering Support", "alias": "gathering_support"}, "stats_views_count": 168, "body": "Look in the Sky. The adventuring Australian and his friends are some of the most beloved characters in LEGO, and their travels have taken them to the enchanted Pyramid of Eternity! This set has heroes, villains, action, Egypt, monsters, and most of all, pure, imaginative, LEGO style adventure!</p>\r\n\r\n<p><br />\r\n<strong>*Note* This project is not an attempt to bring back an old set, but&nbsp;instead to create a brand new set with classic and beloved characters.</strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p><br />\r\nWhile designing the pyramid, I tried to keep the same feel as the classic sets, while still creating a brand new set. The designing of a crumbling structure was a ton of fun to build!</p>\r\n\r\n<p><br />\r\nThe pyramid as well includes numerous tricks and traps to keep Johnny and his pals on their toes. A falling hammer, falling blades, flick-fire missiles, a scorpion pit, a tricky trap door, living giant jackal statues, and a wall that spins around to reveal the evil Pharaoh await the brave adventurers! Will they be able to capture the Pharaoh&rsquo;s staff before he uses the magical ruby to take over the world?</p>\r\n\r\n<p><br />\r\nA small but cozy campsite is included for resting, map examining, and battling!</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Nine minifigures are included:</p>\r\n\r\n<p><br />\r\nJohnny Thunder - Fearless, imaginative, and heroic, Johnny Thunder is truly one of LEGO&rsquo;s greatest heroes.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><br />\r\nHarry Cane &ndash; Nervous ace pilot Harry is one of Johnny&rsquo;s closest friends.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><br />\r\nGail Storm &ndash; Brave and beautiful, Gail is Johnny&rsquo;s girlfriend, and a very intelligent reporter.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><br />\r\nJames Chaos &ndash; Made up for this set, Chaos is the anti-Johnny Thunder: crafty, evil, and almost as tough as Johnny.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><br />\r\nSam Sinister &ndash; Smart, sophisticated, and ruthless, Sam Sinister is a malevolent mastermind, who seeks to steal artifacts for his own gain, specifically the magic ruby.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><br />\r\nBaron Von Barron &ndash; One of the greatest pilots in the world, the Baron seeks to destroy the world&rsquo;s other greatest pilot, Harry Cane, as well as get rich.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><br />\r\nThe Pharaoh &ndash; A pure evil mummy who&rsquo;s trying to take over the world using his mystic staff and the magic ruby.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><br />\r\nFlying Mummy and Jackal Warrior &ndash; These magically strong creatures serve the Pharaoh and no one else.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><br />\r\nIf you&rsquo;re a Johnny Thunder fan and want him to appear in a new, original set with a big pyramid, please support and spread the word. Popular among mercenaries and potential sky-pirates, this is a piece of machinery that can guarantee you a lot&nbsp;of adventures.&nbsp;</em></p>\r\n\r\n<p><em>In case of low fuel, or just a quick rest, the pilot can always retreat to their reserved floating watchtower, where a trained armor-bearer patches up your flying machinery, until the next flight.</em></p>\r\n\r\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Both the two main components,&nbsp;the tower and the aircraft are quite basic builds&nbsp;yet outstanding, and stabile enough for their size,&nbsp;using only &quot;official&quot; building techniques.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The Steamhopper itself is a light and small construction, having enough room to fit a pilot figure&nbsp;and a few accessories inside&nbsp;comfortably. While in landing mode, the rear of the jet folds down&nbsp;while the wings fold to the sides, using clip joints. In this form, the jet is as small as an average lego car, which allows it to interract, or &quot;land&quot; on already existing lego sets, and builds. The jet also contains two detachable &quot;fuel tanks&quot;, one on each wing, which gives a little extra-playability to the set.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The watchtower build gives enough space for the two minifigures, aswell as the accesories. The front part of the build includes a landing pad with a rotating stand, which you can connect your Steamhopper to, using two jumper plates. Even with the jet attached, the watchtower has enough room for the two minifigures to move around&nbsp;and play with.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><em>As a little bonus, the&nbsp;design of the tower&#39;s back side allows the set to connect with three other watchtowers, creating a docking bay. That&nbsp;allows kids to share their sets and play together, or just leaves a classy diorama on your shelf.</em></p>\r\n\r\n<p>The set&nbsp;includes one&nbsp;Steamhopper, a&nbsp;watchtower, a pilot Please share and support this project if you love Lord of the Rings and Middle Earth as much as I do and want to see LEGO Lord of the Rings back on shelves!</p>\r\n\r\n<p><em>Middle-Earth Minis</em> is a series which contains many small, microscale versions of the iconic places in Middle Earth. Since LEGO chose not to produce&nbsp;many locations, hopefully these can cover for some of them. In future updates, I will hopefully be able to create exclusive minifigures that LEGO did not provide us with. Ideally, all of the locations would come in one set with a Middle Earth Map and you could put each microscale version on their according locations.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Here are the locations that are included in Series One.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>Bag End&nbsp;</strong>was a luxurious tunnel&nbsp;on the north-side of&nbsp;Hobbiton&nbsp;built in to the top of The Hill by &nbsp;Bungo Baggins as a wedding gift to his bride&nbsp;Belladonna Took. Only rooms on the west had windows, which opened out like portholes onto a grassy slope and distant meadows beyond. Bilbo lived in this house and Frodo grew up in it. The location is a key starter to both of their adventures.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>Isengard (Orthanc)&nbsp;</strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>Orthanc</strong>&nbsp;is the black tower of Isengard. Orthanc was&nbsp;built during the end of the&nbsp;Second Age&nbsp;by men of&nbsp;Gondor. No known weapon could harm it. &nbsp;Orthanc rose up to more than 500 feet&nbsp;above the plain of Isengard, and ended in four sharp peaks. Its only entrance was at the top of a high stair. Orthanc housed one of the&nbsp;<em>palant&iacute;ri</em>&nbsp;of the South Kingdom, and was guarded by a special warden. When&nbsp;Beren,&nbsp;Steward of Gondor, gave Isengard to the&nbsp;Wizard&nbsp;Saruman, he also gave him the keys of Orthanc. Saruman made it his base of operations during his search for the&nbsp;One Ring&nbsp;and later his attack on Rohan during the&nbsp;War of the Ring. The lush green that surrounded the tower was turned into wasteland and industry.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>Argonath-&nbsp;</strong>A monument comprising two enormous pillars carved in the likenesses of&nbsp;Isildur&nbsp;and&nbsp;An&aacute;rion, standing upon either side of the River&nbsp;Anduin. The figures were originally constructed&nbsp;at the order of King&nbsp;R&oacute;mendacil II&nbsp;to mark the northern border of&nbsp;Gondor. The Fellowship passed through this landmark on their way down the River Anduin from Lorien.&nbsp;Also known as the&nbsp;<strong>Gate of Kings</strong>&nbsp;or the&nbsp;<strong>Pillars of the Kings</strong>.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>Edoras</strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p><span>The capital of Rohan is the hill fort of Edoras which is located on a hill in a valley of the&nbsp;</span>White Mountains<span>. the Golden Hall of the King of Rohan, is located there. </span><span>The city of Edoras was built by&nbsp;</span>Rohan&#39;s second King<span>,&nbsp;</span>Brego<span>&nbsp;son of&nbsp;</span>Eorl the Young<span>. </span><span>The city is protected only by a high wall of timber, and a one-way road allows access to the city. Just before the gates, two rows of&nbsp;</span>mounds<span>&nbsp;line the road, which are the graves of the former Kings of Rohan. The Golden Hall</span><span>&nbsp;serves as a house for the King and his kin, a meeting hall for the King and his advisors, and a gathering hall.</span></p>\r\n\r\n<p><span><strong>Helms Deep</strong></span>&nbsp;was a large valley in the north-western Ered Nimrais (White Mountains). Helms Deep was used a refuge many times by the people of Rohan. It was never breached until Saruman ordered a force of 10,000 uruk-hai to attack it. This is where Aragorn, Legolas, and Gimli defended with the soldiers of Rohan against Saruman&#39;s forces.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><span><strong>Minas Tirith&nbsp;</strong></span>became the heavily fortified capital of Gondor in the second half of the Third Age. It was originally built to guard the former capital, Osgiliath, from attack from the west, but became the capital when Osgiliath fell into ruin. The city was made out of white stone and is considered the most beautiful fortresses ever to be built by men.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>These are all of the locations I have so far, and I have more coming along. The castle is one of Japan&#39;s most famous landmarks and it played a major role in the unification of Japan during the sixteenth century of the Azuchi-Momoyama period. In 1583 Toyotomi Hideyoshi commenced construction on the site of the Ikk\u014d-ikki temple of Ishiyama Hongan-ji. The basic plan was modeled after Azuchi Castle, the headquarters of Oda Nobunaga.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The donjon has eight floors. The&nbsp;first floor&nbsp;has battle spaces and a small&nbsp;&nbsp;pavillion&nbsp;where has a golden statue. The&nbsp;second floor has&nbsp;a couple of room and&nbsp;halls where&nbsp;connected the uppper and lower floors. 278, "body": "<p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Hello!</p>\r\n\r\n<p>So, I started out with the idea to build s working mechanism for the &quot;chicken walker&quot; (At-St) from Star wars - eventually it developed into this, which is a fully functioning robot with a working walking mechanism. the Walker 3000&trade; uses a motor to turn the gears pictured in the third frame,&nbsp;&nbsp;which causes the legs to move using gravity - the legs are attached by axle through basic hole, leaving the legs free -swinging. As the axel moves in a circle, so does the leg. It is a complicated mechanism, using gravity to steady the legs. To us the Lion House both has the history of the company and the architecture qualities to be made into an official LEGO Architecture&nbsp;set.</p>\r\n\r\n<p><strong>The model</strong></p>\r\n\r\n<p>The set is made with all the bricks to make either of two different versions from different times. First the &ldquo;old&rdquo; version which is designed with roof hatches, the brown wooden front &amp; side door and the shop window with &ldquo;LEGO FABRIKEN&rdquo; (LEGO Factory). The second contemporary version has the plain roof, white door and windows.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>The roof is removable and inside you&rsquo;ll find the true history of LEGO - a tile with the patent application from 1958 for a toy building element, a panel with the LEGO&nbsp;Group&#39;s motto &ldquo;<em>det bedste er ikke for godt&rdquo; </em>and a red 2x4 brick<em>.</em></p>\r\n\r\n<p>It&rsquo;s built on a 16x16 studs plate and has around 450 pieces.
